newsitem.title: USA: Raines-U.S. economy better than CBO, OMB forecasts.
newsitem.headline: Raines-U.S. economy better than CBO, OMB forecasts.

text.p: White House budget director Franklin Raines said Wednesday the U.S. economy is doing better than projections by the Congressional Budget Office and the Office of Management and Budget.
The difference in economic forecasts between the OMB and CBO can be a sore point in budget talks because it affects the amount of deficit reduction that needs to take place to balance the budget.
"I think the facts are going to win that argument. The facts are that the economy is performing better than CBO projected and better than we projected," Raines said.
Raines said that there would not be any further substantive negotiations on the budget until after President Clinton meets with House and Senate Democrats this week.
Raines said that he did not see any specific deadline by which budget negotiations had to be resolved.
"I don't plan that we'll go on indefinitely, but I also don't see any one date as being crucial," Raines told reporters.
Raines added that "now we've got to get into narrowing the differences and ultimately the president and the leaders, I think, will have to be involved to close the deal."
The administration is currently considering some of the comment that congressional budget negotiators have made with regard to items in the budget, Raines said.
He said one rule in the budget negotiations is that none of the participants rule anything in or out that is being discussed.
He added that the administration was "quite comfortable" with its stance on Medicare. The White House has proposed $100 billion in savings in Medicare over five years.
"There's a difference on discretionary spending and it is one that will have to be resolved before we have an agreement," Raines said.

On a capital gains tax cut, Raines said the administration has not been convinced yet that it is "necessary from an economic standpoint. We understand that it has a lot of political appeal to Republicans and therefore have been prepared to listen and learn about their views on that."
